Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Business Finance and Financial Markets
headline: Understand the fundamental principles of corporate finance and the financial markets in this free online course.
description: Financial intelligence is of immense importance because most people are a part of the financial system. Savings and retirement accounts make you a player in the financial market. This course will introduce you to business finance, which is concerned with funding and investment decisions in enterprises. You will learn about the intricacies of financial markets and the significance of stocks, bonds, derivatives, annuities and so on. Enrol today.

courseDescription:
From financial analysts and individuals seeking to work in finance to teachers and tradespeople, the financial system has become a fundamental part of daily life. However, with words like ‘inflation’, ‘assets’ and ‘debt’ increasingly being used in casual discussion, understanding economic principles and concepts could be significant to any individual. In this short course, we will introduce you to the basics of finance, emphasising financial markets, instruments and corporate finance, which involves funding and investment decisions by enterprises.

We will begin with an introduction to free-market economies, which form the backbone of most financial systems. You will learn about the all-important ‘time value of money’ (TVM)  and crucial financial instruments and concepts like stocks, bonds, derivatives, interest and annuities. Then investigate the ‘efficient market’ theory, ‘portfolio’ theory, risk and return, interest tax shield and cost of financial distress. Discover how to use methods like the net present value (NPV) to assess the viability of projects and analyse various financial ratios.

Furthermore, we will explore the two methods for market analysis (technical and fundamental analysis) and investigate their merits and demerits. You will also study debt and equity, the two major sources of funding for a business. Finally, we will explain financial forecasting, time series, seasonality and quantitative methods for collecting financial data. By the end of this course, you would have gained sufficient knowledge to plough the fields of corporate finance and financial markets as a whole. So sign up and start learning today.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Fundamentals of Financial Markets & Business Finance
modules.description: This module covers some concepts and instruments of financial markets including the time value of money, interest, bond, and annuities. You will also learn about efficiency and the relationship between risk and return in the financial market. Finally, you will learn about Debt and Equity, financial ratios, and methods for project evaluation.
topics: Financial Markets & Business Finance – Learning Outcomes
Capital Market Theory - Risks and Return
Financial Markets and Business Finance – Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: There are various methods for valuing companies and projects. In this topic, you will learn how discounted and free cash flows are used to value companies and their stocks. You will also be introduced to derivatives in finance. You will learn about futures, options, swaps and how these derivatives are valued in financial markets.
topics: Enterprise Valuation and Derivatives – Learning Outcomes
Enterprise Valuation and Derivatives – Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: Analysis of a company and its stock can be carried out using one of two methods, fundamental and technical analysis. In this topic, you will learn about technical analysis, which involves analysing market trends to predict the future movements of a stock. You will also learn about seasonality and financial forecasting, and the use of IT in finance.
topics: Technical Analysis and Financial Forecasting – Learning Outcomes
Technical Analysis and Financial Forecasting – Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
topics: Business Finance & Financial Markets – Course assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this module, you should be able to;
    • Discuss the time value of money (TVM).
    • Explain the efficient market hypothesis, and the different types of efficiency.
    • Analyse the merits and demerits of debt and equity as sources of finance for a business.
    • Identify commonly used project valuation methods.
    • Explain the importance of financial ratio analysis.
    • Outline some financial ratios used in analysing businesses.
    • Describe the relationship between risk and return in financial markets.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Finance deals with allocation and expenditure of capital, flow of cash and the cost of capital.
    • Sound financial discipline benefits both consumers and investors, in turn improving the whole economic system.
    • Finance has four main subfields; capital markets, investment, financial institutions and corporate finance.
    • Time Value of Money suggests that, in general, the earlier funds are secured and received, the better the financial outcome.
    • Two of the underlying reasons for delaying current consumption and investing funds for future gains are risk and inflation.
    • Discount Cash Flow applies a discount rate (r) to the future cashflows of a project to obtain a present value.
    • Terminal value (TV) is the value of cash inflow at the end of an investment.
    • Interest rates fall when there is an excess of funds in an economy, and rise when funds are short in supply.
    • A bond is a financial instrument with a fixed obligation to pay periodical interest payments as well as the final payment of the principal to the investors

  • Lesson Summary

    • Finance deals with allocation and expenditure of capital, flow of cash and the cost of capital.
    • Sound financial discipline benefits both consumers and investors, in turn improving the whole economic system.
    • Finance has four main subfields; capital markets, investment, financial institutions and corporate finance.
    • Time Value of Money suggests that, in general, the earlier funds are secured and received, the better the financial outcome.
    • Two of the underlying reasons for delaying current consumption and investing funds for future gains are risk and inflation.
    • Discount Cash Flow applies a discount rate (r) to the future cashflows of a project to obtain a present value.
    • Terminal value (TV) is the value of cash inflow at the end of an investment.
    • Interest rates fall when there is an excess of funds in an economy, and rise when funds are short in supply.
    • A bond is a financial instrument with a fixed obligation to pay periodical interest payments as well as the final payment of the principal to the investors

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this module, you will be able to;
    • Identify methods for valuating companies.
    • Distinguish between futures and options contracts.
    • Outline the differences between American-style and European-style options.
    • Explain how derivatives are different from securities.
    • Define dividends.
    • Discuss the factors that determine the value of derivatives.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The goal of company valuation is to give owners, potential buyers and other interested stakeholders an approximate value of what a company is worth.
    • Cash equivalents represent investments that can readily be converted to cash. Marketable securities, treasury bills, commercial paper, and short term government bonds are typical examples of cash equivalents.
    • When there are no current or future prospects for profit generation, the emphasis for valuation is on the value of assets in the business.
    • There are two approaches to valuing stock; fundamental analysis and technical analysis. Fundamental analysts assess whether a company's stock is undervalued or overvalued based on its business prospects.
    • Under the dividend discount model (DDM) the present value of future dividends is considered as the price of the stock.
    • Financial markets deal with primary assets and also derivative assets. A derivative is a financial instrument whose price is determined based on another underlying asset - or a class of assets.
    • As well as being used as an instrument to gain speculative profits, derivatives could also be used to hedge risk.
    • Exchange-traded derivatives are publicly traded on an exchange, while over the counter (OTC) derivatives are traded privately.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The goal of company valuation is to give owners, potential buyers and other interested stakeholders an approximate value of what a company is worth.
    • Cash equivalents represent investments that can readily be converted to cash. Marketable securities, treasury bills, commercial paper, and short term government bonds are typical examples of cash equivalents.
    • When there are no current or future prospects for profit generation, the emphasis for valuation is on the value of assets in the business.
    • There are two approaches to valuing stock; fundamental analysis and technical analysis. Fundamental analysts assess whether a company's stock is undervalued or overvalued based on its business prospects.
    • Under the dividend discount model (DDM) the present value of future dividends is considered as the price of the stock.
    • Financial markets deal with primary assets and also derivative assets. A derivative is a financial instrument whose price is determined based on another underlying asset - or a class of assets.
    • As well as being used as an instrument to gain speculative profits, derivatives could also be used to hedge risk.
    • Exchange-traded derivatives are publicly traded on an exchange, while over the counter (OTC) derivatives are traded privately.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this module, you will be able to;
    • Recall the four patterns that could be predicted using time series data.
    • Distinguish between futures and options contracts.
    • Outline some examples of seasonal stock market trends.
    • Compare technical analysis and fundamental analysis.
    • Identify the trend types in technical analysis.
    • Recall common smoothing techniques used in financial analysis.

  • IT Systems in Finance

  • Different financial management software is available in the market for financial management and modelling.

    There is also financial ratio analysis software used to conduct a detailed analysis of a business's financial performance and position and to compare its performance with competing firms or industry averages.

    A financial analysis software should be capable of the following
    • Planning, budgeting, and forecasting.
    • Measurement and management of cost and profitability.
    • Financial and management reporting.
    • Current assets, cash flows and working capital management.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • To be useful and widely acceptable, the inbuilt features of a financial management or ratio analysis software should be aligned to the strategic objectives of an organization.

    It should also be flexible enough to be integrated with the firm’s existing accounting and information systems.

  • IT Systems in Finance

  • Different financial management software is available in the market for financial management and modelling.

    There is also financial ratio analysis software used to conduct a detailed analysis of a business's financial performance and position and to compare its performance with competing firms or industry averages.

    A financial analysis software should be capable of the following
    • Planning, budgeting, and forecasting.
    • Measurement and management of cost and profitability.
    • Financial and management reporting.
    • Current assets, cash flows and working capital management.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • To be useful and widely acceptable, the inbuilt features of a financial management or ratio analysis software should be aligned to the strategic objectives of an organization.

    It should also be flexible enough to be integrated with the firm’s existing accounting and information systems.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Technical analysis is a method of evaluating securities by analyzing the statistics generated by market activity, such as past prices and volume. 
    • All the chart patterns or oscillators used by technical analysts are derived using historical price and volume data.
    • Technical analysis has three major assumptions; the market factors everything, prices move in trends, and history repeats itself.
    • There are three types of trends, uptrends, downtrends, and sideways trends. Support and resistance are formed at points where bulls and bears are unable to overcome each other.
    • Support and resistance need to be monitored by technical traders because they confirm trends. Once the price breaks a support level, that level becomes a resistance level, and vice versa.
    • Volume is used to corroborate patterns demonstrated by charts. In technical analysis, price leads volume as a signal.
    • Using moving averages, price fluctuations can be smoothed out, making it easier to identify trends. 
    • Exponential moving averages are preferred over linear ones since they place a higher value on recent price observations.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Technical analysis is a method of evaluating securities by analyzing the statistics generated by market activity, such as past prices and volume. 
    • All the chart patterns or oscillators used by technical analysts are derived using historical price and volume data.
    • Technical analysis has three major assumptions; the market factors everything, prices move in trends, and history repeats itself.
    • There are three types of trends, uptrends, downtrends, and sideways trends. Support and resistance are formed at points where bulls and bears are unable to overcome each other.
    • Support and resistance need to be monitored by technical traders because they confirm trends. Once the price breaks a support level, that level becomes a resistance level, and vice versa.
    • Volume is used to corroborate patterns demonstrated by charts. In technical analysis, price leads volume as a signal.
    • Using moving averages, price fluctuations can be smoothed out, making it easier to identify trends. 
    • Exponential moving averages are preferred over linear ones since they place a higher value on recent price observations.
